contextId.information: Yahweh is speaking about himself as if he were another person. AT: "to obey what I, Yahweh, require ... I, Yahweh, may bring ... I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: to keep the way of Yahweh ... Yahweh may bring ... he has said

contextId.information: Abraham shows his respect to Yahweh by speaking to Yahweh as if he were speaking to someone else. AT: "to you, my Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Lot refers to himself as their servant in order to show them respect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The phrase "your servant" is a polite way for Jacob to refer to himself. AT: "These are the children God has kindly given me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: The children whom God has graciously given your servant

contextId.information: This is a polite and formal way of referring to Esau. AT: "You, my master, know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
God speaks about himself in the third person. AT: "Build an altar there to me, your God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: Build an altar there to God

contextId.information: The cupbearer is referring to Pharaoh in third person. This is a common way for someone with less power to speak to someone with greater power. AT: "You, Pharaoh, were angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Here "his" refers to the cupbearer and baker individually, not to the one interpreting the dream. AT: "He explained what was going to happen to both of us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: He interpreted for each of us according to his dream

contextId.information: Here the cupbearer uses Pharaoh's title in speaking to him as a way of honoring him. AT: "You allowed me to return to my job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: Pharaoh restored me to my post

contextId.information: Here "he" refers to Pharaoh. And, it stands for the soldiers that Pharaoh commanded to hang the chief baker. AT: "you ordered your soldiers to hang" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Joseph speaks to Pharaoh in the third person. This is a way of showing respect. It can be stated in the second person. AT: "God is showing you what he will soon do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: What God is about to do, he has declared to Pharaoh

contextId.information: Joseph speaks to Pharaoh in the third person. This is a way of showing respect. It can be stated in second person. AT: "These events will happen just as I have told you ... revealed to you, Pharaoh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: That is the thing which I spoke to Pharaoh ... revealed to Pharaoh

contextId.information: Joseph speaks to Pharaoh in third person. This is a way of showing respect. It can be stated in second person. AT: "You, Pharaoh, should look" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "We, your servants, have" or "We have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in the first person. Also, "is is found" can be stated in active form. AT: "If you find that one of us has stolen the cup" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: With whomever of your servants it is found

contextId.information: The brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in first person. AT: "our iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Judah refers to himself as "your servant." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in first person. AT: "let me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here "my master" refers to Joseph. This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in second person. AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Judah refers to Joseph with the words "my master" and "his." He also refers to himself and his brothers as "his servants." AT: "You, my master, asked us, your servants" or "You asked us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Judah refers to Joseph as "my master." Also, "words" stands for what was said. AT: "we told him what you said, my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: we told him the words of my master

contextId.information: Judah refers to himself as "your servant." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "let me, your servant" or "let me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

Joseph's brothers refer to themselves as "your servants." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with more authority. This can be stated in first person. AT: "We, your servants" or "We" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

The people refer to Joseph as "my master." This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in second person. AT: "We will not hide from you, our master" or "We will not hide from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: We will not hide from my master

contextId.information: Jacob is referring to himself in the third person. It can be stated in the first person. AT: "my sons. Listen to me, your father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: you sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father

contextId.information: The brothers are referring to themselves as "the servants of the God of your father." This can be stated in first person. AT: "please forgive us, the servants of the God of our father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
contextId.quote: please forgive the servants of the God of your father
